title: Australia’s artificial intelligence plan explained
description: Security and defence expert Ian Langford explains the Australian government’s launch of a national artificial intelligence plan.  “Where I think AI and policy needs to really focus on is how it leverages that technology in terms of productivity and growth,” Mr Langford told Sky News Australia.  “We’re seeing globally that the AI investment and the hyper scaling of data and technology, particularly around onshoring and bringing sovereignty to those opportunities, is where the policy needs to be.  “What I’m looking forward to is understanding how the government intends to turbocharge productivity, on how it intends to bring the future into the Australian workplace, and how it seeks to secure growth pathways.”

title: ‘Discussion we can’t have’: Pauline Hanson attends anti-immigration protest
description: Sky News contributor Louise Roberts praises One Nation Leader Pauline Hanson for participating in discussions about immigration.  “This is a discussion we can’t seem to have without protests and mudslinging and the insults that were slung at Pauline herself on Monday,” Ms Roberts told Sky News host Rita Panahi.  “There was both sides of the immigration debate in the Flagstaff Gardens, and we didn’t have any meaningful dialogue between them.  “I think Pauline speaks for a lot of the quiet Australians who don’t feel they can ask questions about how migration affects us and how mass migration in particular affects us.”

title: Nigel Farage remains ‘on top’ despite latest polling showing a ‘big drop in support’
description: Sky News host Andrew Bolt claims the polls were showing Reform UK leader Nigel Farage looking like a “runaway winner” at the next election amid soaring support.  “Anti-immigration, anti-net zero, it was all working,” Mr Bolt said.  He said, however, now the polls indicate a “big drop in support” for Mr Farage’s Reform UK Party.

title: ‘He should sue if this is true’: BBC make-up artists allegedly used ‘bodily fluids’ on Farage
description: ‘Triggered with Samara Gill’ host Samara Gill has commented on a shocking claim by historian Lisa Hilton, who has presented BBC TV documentaries, about the national broadcaster’s make-up artists.  Ms Hilton claims that BBC make-up artists allegedly used human saliva and other bodily fluids on Reform UK leader Nigel Farage during his appearance on the network.  “This is shocking. The hatred is off the scales,” Ms Gill told Sky News host Andrew Bolt.  “It’s ridiculous, and it’s outrageous, and he should sue if this is true.”

title: One in every 27 Australian children is diagnosed with autism
description: Sky News contributor Louise Roberts raises concerns after it has been revealed more Australian children than ever are being diagnosed with autism, with a 35 per cent surge in the past four years.  Analysis of data from the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) shows more than 220,000 children around the country with an autism spectrum disorder diagnosis are receiving financial support.  Now, one in every 27 Australian children is being diagnosed with autism.  “Are we diagnosing more or are we diagnosing better?” Ms Roberts told Sky News host Rita Panahi.  “If we’ve got parents who feel that unless they put a label on their child, they won't get any support.  “We don’t want to incentivise people to label their children and set them on the path of autism if it’s not accurate.”

title: Labor’s electricity modelling was ‘wrong’ as costs increase
description: ​Herald Sun’s Associate Editor James Campbell claims the “modelling was wrong,” as a report shows higher electricity costs under the Albanese government.    ​“It was good modelling at the time, and subsequent events have shown it was not up to the task,” Mr Campbell told Sky News Australia.  ​“It's a very sad scenario.”

title: ‘Huge incentive’: NDIS support encourages parents to classify kids as disabled
description: Institute of Public Affairs Chief Economist Adam Creighton warns that in offering NDIS support, it may actually incentivise parents to pursue incorrect diagnoses for their children.   “If that doctor says no, the parents will find some other doctor who will say yes,” Mr Creighton told Sky News host Rita Panahi.  “The NDIS creates a huge incentive to be classified as disabled.  “This was a scheme that was forecast to have a few hundred thousand at most on it, back when it was first proposed ten years ago, and now we’re coming up to a million.”

title: Ellen DeGeneres’ UK neighbours reportedly ‘do not like’ her
description: ‘Kinsey Schofield Unfiltered’ host Kinsey Schofield reveals what Ellen DeGeneres’ neighbours think of her in the UK.   “From her current neighbours in the UK, they don’t like her, they aren’t friendly towards her, and they hate all of the celebrities like Ellen moving into this one sacred and anonymous area,” Ms Schofield told Sky News host Rita Panahi.  “They wish American celebrities would stay in America.  “They are welcoming the thought of Ellen returning to the States.”

title: Trump administration launches review into Afghan nationals let in under Biden
description: White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said the Trump administration will be reviewing all Afghans who came to the United States during Biden's term.  This comes after two National Guard members were shot in Washington, DC by an alleged Afghan national.  Accused Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal will face a first-degree murder charge.  Formal charges were not immediately filed against Lakanwal, who had been in the US since 2021 under a program of then-president Joe Biden's administration.  US President Donald Trump spoke on his administration's decision to halt all asylum decisions and pause issuing visas for people travelling on Afghan passports.  Trump also invited the family of the National Guard member who was fatally shot last week to the White House.

title: Hollywood will ‘punish’ Ellen if she comes to US due to her disgraceful professional behaviour
description: ‘Kinsey Schofield Unfiltered’ host Kinsey Schofield claims Ellen DeGeneres is moving back to the US for the “desire for a professional comeback”.   “I do think she’s bored, of course she’s bored,” Ms Schofield told Sky News host Rita Panahi.   “Netflix gave her a new special not too long ago, it got no traction.  “I don’t think Hollywood is really ready for her return. I think they will continue to punish her.”

title: Trump destroys ‘lousy’ reporter over question about his ‘perfect’ health
description: US President Donald Trump has flamed a reporter following being questioned about his recent MRI scan while answering questions on Air Force One.  The president told the reporter it was fine to release his MRI results because they were "perfect."  Trump then followed with a quick jab at a reporter's network, NewsNation, saying they were "failing" and doing "lousy."  White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt also defended the president's MRI, saying it was part of his "comprehensive executive physical."

title: ‘Real trouble’: Government launching AI plan
description: ​Herald Sun’s Associate Editor James Campbell weighs in on the government’s national AI plan, which will accelerate the adoption of AI.  ​Mr Campbell told Sky News Australia that professions such as doctors and lawyers are in “real trouble”.  ​“These sorts of jobs for the first time are really going to feel the cold winds of tech change.”

title: DC shooting shows ‘historic failures’ of the Biden administration still 'haunt' the US
description: White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt has ripped into the Biden administration for its “botched” withdrawal from Afghanistan.  The press secretary’s blasting comes after two National Guard troops were shot in Washington, DC.  The shooter was an Afghan national who was brought to America under Biden’s ‘Operation Allies Welcome’, which began in August 2021.  It is reported that one of the victims, U.S. Air Force Staff Sergeant Andrew Wolfe, is still in critical condition, and U.S. Army Specialist Sarah Beckstrom tragically died from her wounds.  Leavitt, in her statement, said the withdrawal was one of the “most embarrassing” moments in US history.  The press secretary also says Biden’s “historic failure” in Afghanistan continues to “haunt” the US.

title: New York in crisis after city releases nearly 7,000 illegal migrant criminals and maniacs
description: New York state has shockingly released nearly 7,000 illegal migrant criminals and failed to notify Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).  According to the Department of Homeland Security, the mass release of criminals has occurred since US President Donald Trump took over the White House.  The state of New York also has over 7,000 other known illegal migrant criminals locked up in jails and prisons, DHS confirmed.  Homeland Security revealed the migrant criminals are protected by New York’s sanctuary laws, but are now demanding they be handed over for deportation.  The DHS added that the migrants released by New York state have committed thousands of crimes, including violent offences.  ICE were not notified of the release of the violent and non-violent offenders, with many freed without bail or parole.

title: Victoria introduces the most ‘poll-driven’ piece of legislation on crime: James Campbell
description: ​Herald Sun’s Associate Editor James Campbell discusses Victoria’s new crime laws, under which teenagers could spend life sentences in prison for serious crimes.  ​“They’re [Labor] genuinely scared if they don't do something … if they're not seen as being tough, they will be in all sorts of bother at the next election,” Mr Campbell told Sky News Australia.  ​“It’s the most poll-driven piece of legislation I've ever seen.  ​“Now, we've got 14-year-olds potentially being locked up for life.”
